title: How to become a 32 degree mason - Quora

response.answer_text: The first three degrees of Masonry are conferred in the local lodge, or Blue Lodge as it is often known. These are the Entered Apprentice (EA), Fellowcraft (FC), and Master Mason (MM). Those are the highest degrees in Masonry. The Scottish Rite confers the 4th through 32nd Degrees as a part of its work but they are not considered to make anyone “more of a Mason” than he already is. It always make me laugh when someone says their uncle or whoever was a 32nd degree Mason as if that was really an achievement. Being made a 32nd degree Mason is nothing more than a Master Mason paying a fee to the Scottish Rite and attending a Reunion (meeting), normally held two or three times a year, and receiving the 29 degrees via exemplification or communication. My fee was $175, but that varies by region. In Oklahoma we normally confer all 29 degrees at the same Reunion. Normally this is accomplished in two days although there have been some one day conferrals. In either case many of the degrees are communicated. For the benefit of those readers not familiar with the Scottish Rite the degrees are either “exemplified” by means of a short play, or “communicated” by having someone summarize the lessons the play would have taught. Certain degrees are required to be exemplified. I received my degrees in a special 3-day conferral at which all 29 degrees were exemplified and that was highly unusual. I know in earlier times the degrees were presented over an extended period of time and in Europe that is still often the case. Truth is, I know some brethren who Petitioned for the Degrees, one month later received their E.A. degree and on the following weekend got a one-day conferral of the FC and MM degrees and the following weekend received a one-day conferral at the Scottish Rite. This was all properly timed, with a Grand Master’s time dispensation, to take a man off the street to 32 degree in less than two months. If the new Brother had the next weekend free the Shrine or York Rite were ready and waiting. If you can’t tell, my preference is for a Brother to witness as many of the degrees as possible and to regularly return to watch them again and again. There are many valuable lessons that will be lost if you do not see them often enough. Nearly everyone will tell you that you will learn more each time you see them. Nor do I in any way diminish the value of being a Scottish Rite Mason by emphasizing how easily it may be obtained. I am simply saying that the 32nd Degree is not some secret deep inner circle. Its degrees are all beautiful in both presentation and content, something I strongly recommend to all Master Masons. Beyond the 32nd degree (Black caps) is the 32nd Degree, Knight Commander, Court of Honor which is a distinction rather than a degree. The 32nd KCCH (Red caps) is award to 32nd degree Masons for their work or other activity. The 33rd Degree, Inspector General Honorary (White caps) is reserved for men who provided substantial benefit and service to the Scottish Rite. Finally, there is the 33rd Degree Grand Cross (White cap with blue band) that is extremely rare and bestowed on 33rd Degree IGH Masons who have contributed greatly to Masonry, generally through research. All of these higher recognitions as subject to time served at the previous level, limited to a percentage of the membership, and if requested must be denied.

Freemasonry is made up of three degrees.  When someone joins, he goes through the process of receiving the degrees and becomes a third degree Master Mason.  At this point, he is a full Member of the Fraternity and a peer to all other Masons throughout the world. Within Freemasonry, there are sub-groups that exist for a variety of purposes.  Each of these groups uses different titles, structure, etc.  One such group is called the Scottish Rite. The Scottish Rite is made up of 29 "degrees."  These degrees are numbered 4 through 32, but they are not higher than the Third (Master Mason) Degree.  When someone joins the Scottish Rite, he goes through an initiation process culminating with him receiving the 32nd degree of the Scottish Rite [note: most Members do not receive all 29 degrees, but they all receive the 32nd].

By 32°Mason,  you are speaking of the Scottish Rite which is an appendant body of Masonry. To become a 32° Mason, you must first become a Master Mason. To do that,  you must petition a lodge, be accepted,  be initiated to the degree of Entered Apprentice, passed to the degree of Fellowcraft, and raised to the sublime degree of Master Mason,  or 3rd ° Mason.  A 32° Mason is not higher than a 3rd° Mason.  The highest degree in Masonry is the 3rd degree The Scottish Rite is, simply more learning and education. http://scottishrite.org/

Join the Masons and complete your first three blue lodge degrees then complete a petition for the Scottish Rite pay your dues and complete the 4 through the 32nd degree and whaalla you are the 32nd degree, Mason but you will have no clue what you just did unless you are serious about it and take the time to study and learn its meaning.

There's no such thing as a 32 degree mason.  There is, however, a 32nd Degree in the Scottish Rite. To attain the degree in this appendant body, a man must first become a Master Mason. Once they have attained this degree, they can petition to join the Scottish Rite. Once voted in, the Master Mason attends the classes and participates in he degrees until he reaches the 32nd Degree.

As others have stated, the 32degree is part of the Scottish Rite, an appendant body of Masonry. It involves much study and exemplification, usually stretched out over months, and (to me, at least), very interesting and informative. It does not make you any more, or higher rank of Mason, than the 3rd Degree, or Master Mason.I wish you good fortune in your pursuit of Truth!
